I don't understand how you can't understand that a huge portion of Nashville MLS fans would come from small towns and cities outside of the metro area. That's how it is in the south with every pro team, including MLS (see Atlanta United). San Diego doesn't have a huge population to pull fans from like that because for the 1,000 time it's hemmed in on 2 sides by 2 large cities. There isn't a large area full of small towns and cities that San Diego is the principal city for. No other city in MLS suffers from this except San Diego. It's a geographic anomaly, and unfortunately for San Diego it limits the amount of fans they could have
The area that Nashville draws from is much larger than the San Diego metro area. Middle Tennessee + north Alabama + east TN + west TN is far more people than San Diego. You can't say "oh but if you count people in LA it's more" because people in LA live and care about LA, not San Diego. That would be like saying, "People in Nashville are going to be Atlanta United fans even if Nashville got a MLS team." If San Diego wasn't crammed between 2 larger cities San Diego would have a larger area but they are so it's a mute point.

It's funny that you think I care what a snobby little Canadian man thinks of my country. By the way, "modern history" is basically defined as 1800 to modern day. History from the 70ish onward can't be subjectively viewed because it's too recent and we can't see the full effects of those actions yet.
Source: History major with a focus on the early modern era
Name one major nation that has never done similar things or colonized large sections of the world. Yeah we have a past but so does everybody else.

Mexico is building a wall on their southern border to keep Central Americans out. Various European nations have border walls. Qatar treats Indian immigrant workers as fourth class citizens. Russia recently invaded a sovereign nation and stole their land. Why do Americans have a "woe unto us" attitude about everything? We aren't perfect but we are one of the leaders of democracy across the world.

It's such a double standard. Russia is a de facto dictatorship and human rights violator, and Qatar uses literally slave labor, but the USA can't hold a bid because we have a president that some people don't agree with.

I actually kind of like this. In America there are a lot of really smart people that end up being in tons of debt because of college, because their families made too much money to get FASFA and other grants. While there are people from poor families that are terrible students that get nearly 100% full government assistance.
For example my roommate has his college 100% paid for by the government even though his ACT test score was around a 19 and his current GPA in college is a 2.5. I got a 26 on the ACT and currently have a 4.0 GPA in college but pay for about 85% of tuition because my family didn't qualify for government assistance
Tennessee has 100% free community college education.

I think MLS suffers from the same thing MLB does. In the cities where MLS/MLB are popular it's a huge deal. They are soccer/baseball cities. However outdide of those markets literally nobody cares. Nobody outside of the metropolitan areas like Portland, Seattle, etc cares about MLS. To be fair only the NFL and NBA have popularity outside of metropolitan areas. For instance go to rural Texas and you'll still find NFL NBA fans, but hardly any MLB or MLS fans. Idk how you fix that but I think there are a lot of snobby MLS fans that don't care what people outside of major metro areas care. That's over half of the American population that MLS has zero penetration into, and honestly it seems like MLS doesn't care. As long as they don't care about that demographic they will be third, fourth, or fifth fiddle in America sports
I see this as a net gain. MLS needs to gain sway with the huge English speaking majority in this country. The Spanish speakers already watch soccer.
